; Sat, 21 Oct 2023 02:22:02 +0800 â€˜A lot on the lineâ€™: New Zealandâ€™s youngest MP looks to MÄori ancestors to build new futurehttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/oct/20/a-lot-on-the-line-new-zealands-youngest-mp-looks-to-maori-ancestors-to-build-new-future
;;2023-10-20T18:00:24Z;
;
;;Hana-Rawhiti Maipi-Clarke became New Zealand's youngest MP after entering parliament after last week's elections.
;

;On her first day in New Zealand's parliament, the country's youngest politician Hana-Rawhiti Maipi-Clarke beelined to a wall of photographs to seek out an image of her ancestor â€“ the first MÄori minister to the crown.

;

;â€œI felt so relieved after seeing that picture,â€ Maipi-Clarke tells the Guardian. â€œ[parliament] house is very overwhelming for women, for MÄori and especially for young people â€“ there is a lot on the line for us.â€

;

;â€œHis photograph was a good sign â€“ I said, you gotta have my back up in here,â€ she said.

;
;

;;Related: ;;New Zealand Labour shed votes to the right but also the left â€“ the price of a progressive policy bonfire;

;
;

;At just 21 years old Maipi-Clarke became the youngest MP in 170 years to enter New Zealand's parliament in last week's national elections. In the process, she unseated Labour's ;Nanaia Mahuta;, one of the country's most senior and respected MPs, who was the first MÄori foreign affairs minister and had held the Hauraki-Waikato ;MÄori electorate ;for 20 years.

;

;But the novice MÄori party â€“ or Te PÄti MÄori â€“ politician is no newcomer to politics: it is in her blood.

;

;As well as Maipi-Clarke's great-great-great-great-grandfather Wiremu Katene â€“ who was the first MÄori minister to the Crown in 1872 â€“ her aunty, Hana Te Hemara, was responsible for delivering the MÄori language petition to parliament in 1972, and in 2018 her grandfather, Taitimu Maipi, made headlines for vandalising a statue of Capt John Hamilton â€“ the namesake of Hamilton city â€“ in protest against Hamilton's colonial legacy and brutality towards MÄori.

;

;Maipi-Clarke hails from Huntly â€“ a small town between Auckland and Hamilton â€“ where she runs a mÄra kai â€“ a MÄori community garden that educates local children about gardening to maramataka, or planting in line with the MÄori lunar calendar. Her resume belies her years, as well as being a business owner, she has also ;written a book ;that encourages rangatahi (young people) to take an interest in the stars and the moon to heal themselves.

;

;Maipi-Clarke does not see herself as a politician â€“ rather she sees her role as a kaitiaki (guardian) for MÄori language, the land and for traditional knowledge, and believes it is time for a new generation of MÄori voices to be heard.

;

;With 20,000 followers on Instagram and another 18,500 on TikTok, Maipi-Clarke knows her audience. â€œWhether you're MÄori, Pacific, non-MÄori, we're really missing the translation to the public who may not have any understanding of politics,â€ she says.

;

;But Maipi-Clarke is quick to add that her campaign on social media is just half the story.

;

;â€œThe amount of gas I used to go around our whole electorate to meet face-to-face with the older generations â€¦ I truly believe I was running two campaigns with two different strategies and they were equally important.â€

;

;'They voted for a party that looked like them'

;

;Maipi-Clarke's win in the Hauraki-Waikato MÄori electorate came as a surprise to many: opinion polls predicted Mahuta would hold the seat. Mahuta's confidence in retaining her seat was such that she didn't run for Labour as a list MP â€“ those MPs who fill seats from the party's preference list as opposed to an electorate â€“ and consequently, her 27-year career in parliament has ended.

;

;â€œIt was a surprise, because Nanaia Mahuta has held the seat for many years now and is a political legacy,â€ says Mihingarangi Forbes, a veteran MÄori broadcaster, television presenter and political journalist.

;

;But Maipi-Clarke's win was not entirely unpredictable, Forbes adds. Not only is roughly 75% of the MÄori population under 40, the median age for MÄori in the Hauraki-Waikato electorate is 23.

;

;Maipi-Clarke also represents the first generation of MÄori who have been educated through the three stages of MÄori language immersion schools.

;

;She is â€œabsolutely the exampleâ€ of who is coming out of this movement, Forbes says. â€œLike unions and the Labour party, like business and the National party, MÄori immersion is becoming the movement behind Te PÄti MÄori,â€ she says. â€œI hear it, I see it on T-shirts, I see it on TikTok â€“ people are talking about this movement, and Hana-Rawhiti has ridden that wave in.â€

;

;Te PÄti MÄori had a strong showing in the election â€“ taking out four of the seven MÄori electorate seats. The party could also nab another two with a close margin, once the special votes â€“ those made overseas or from outside a voter's electorate â€“ are counted. Te PÄti MÄori's success is less about punishing Labour's MÄori MPs, and more about a greater appetite for change, Forbes says.

;

;â€œWe're good at deciding how to pick leaders and making sure your vote works â€“ they voted for a party that looked like them, talked like them.â€

;

;Forbes hopes that Maipi-Clarke â€“ who faced ;threats and home invasions; during a campaign that was marred with accusations of race-baiting from other parties â€“ will be protected by more senior MPs. â€œI would hate to have my children in parliament, but [Maipi-Clarke] comes with a fighting spirit from a whÄnau that has always stood up.â€

;

;After a frantic week of inductions, media-appearances and meetings, Maipi-Clarke is ready to face the future.

;

;â€œA huge priority for me is building my electorate â€¦ but importantly â€¦ I think it's a prime opportunity for MÄori in and out of parliament to put together our plan for the kind of government we will face.â€

; Sat, 21 Oct 2023 02:22:02 +0800 Chinese ship is focus of investigation into damaged pipeline, Finland sayshttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/oct/20/chinese-ship-is-focus-of-investigation-into-damaged-pipeline-finland-says
;;2023-10-20T18:04:24Z;
;
;;The Finnish border guard's patrol vessel at sea near where the pipeline was damaged.
;

;Finnish police have said a Chinese ship whose movement coincided with the â€œtime and placeâ€ of the suspected sabotage of ;a pipeline between Finland and Estonia that was damaged this month; is now the focus of their investigation.

;

;After a leak led to the shutdown of the Balticconnector pipeline on 8 October, Finnish authorities have been investigating the damage which they say was caused by â€œexternalâ€ activity.

;

;On Friday they said their focus was on the Newnew Polar Bear, a cargo ship that reportedly came under Chinese ownership this year. Between 2017 and 2022 it was known as the Baltic Fulmar, Finnish broadcaster YLE reported.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Nato vows to respond if Finland-Estonia gas pipeline damage is deliberate;

;
;

;â€œThe movements of the vessel Newnew Polar Bear flying the flag of Hong Kong coincide with the time and place of the gas pipeline damage,â€ Finland's National Bureau of Investigation said in a statement.

;

;Det Supt Risto Lohi said: â€œWe will cooperate with Chinese authorities in order to establish the role of the said vessel.â€

;

;Police also confirmed the damage was caused by â€œan external mechanical forceâ€ and that they had found â€œa heavy objectâ€ near the damaged pipeline.

;

;â€œA recently formed huge clump of soil containing probably an extremely heavy object has been found in the seabed,â€ Lohi said.

;

;The police will attempt to lift the object from the seabed, where it lies deep in the clay, to investigate whether it is connected to the damaged pipeline.

;

;The National Bureau of Investigation said this week it was investigating Newnew Polarbear and a Russian ship, Sevmorput, both of which they said were in the area at the time of the incident.

;

;After completing its crime scene investigation into the gas pipeline damage on Thursday, samples are now being analysed in in the bureau's forensic library.

;

;It will take at least five months to repair the pipeline, its operator said last week, leaving Finland totally dependent upon liquefied natural gas imports for the winter.

;

;Natural gas accounts for around 5% of Finland's energy consumption, mainly used in industry and combined heat and power production.

;

;Last year, underwater explosions resulted in the rupture of three pipelines in the Baltic Sea responsible for the transportation of natural gas from Russia to Western Europe.
